explanation: The report is correct. If url points to an empty string (""), strcmp(url, "/") returns non-zero so the code enters the file-download branch. There the code computes &url[1] and reads url[1] (the test '/' != url[1]) and passes &url[1] to functions that expect a NUL-terminated string (strstr, strrchr, open treating it as path). For an empty string the object has only index 0 (the terminating '\0') and &url[1] is a pointer one-past-the-end; dereferencing it or passing it to functions that will read through the pointed-to characters is undefined behavior and amounts to accesses beyond the bounds of the object. That violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. (The code implicitly assumes the request-target has at least one character after index 0, but MISRA requires the code to prevent out-of-bounds access for all possible inputs.)
